info.title: Reservoir API
info.description: You are viewing the reference docs for the Reservoir API. For a more complete overview with guides and examples, check out the Reservoir Protocol Docs.

tags.name: 1. Order Book
tags.description: Read & write from Reservoir's open, aggregated order book

tags.name: 2. Aggregator
tags.description: Access normalized pricing and sales data, to feed into your own system

tags.name: 3. Router
tags.description: Simple APIs to create and fill liquidity from any supported exchange protocol

tags.name: 4. NFT API
tags.description: Build a complete application with rich NFT endpoints

tags.name: 6. Search
tags.description: Lightweight search APIs optimized for searching collections/tokens

get.summary: Get all activity events
get.description: This API can be used to scrape all of the activities

get.summary: List of valid orders.
get.description: Access orders with various filters applied. If you need orders created by a single user, use the positions API instead.

parameters.name: token

parameters.name: tokenSetId

get.summary: Get recent sales for a contract or token
get.description: Note: this API is returns rich metadata, and has advanced filters, so is only designed for small amounts of recent sales. If you want access to sales in bulk, use the `Aggregator > Bulk Sales` API.

get.description: This API is optimized for quickly fetching a list of tokens in a collection, sorted by price, with only the most important information returned. If you need more metadata, use the `tokens/details` API

get.summary: Buy any token at the best available price
Buy any token at the best available price
Cancel an existing order
List a token for sale
List a token for sale.
Sell any token at the best available price (accept bid)
Sell any token at the best available price (accept bid)
User liquidity rankings
get.description: This API calculates the total liquidity created by users, based on the number of tokens they are top bidder for.

get.summary: Bulk access to raw orders
get.description: This API is designed for efficiently ingesting large volumes of orders, for external processing

get.summary: Get a list of asks (listings), filtered by token, collection or maker
get.description: This API is designed for efficiently ingesting large volumes of orders, for external processing

parameters.description: Filter to a particular user, e.g. `0x4d04eb67a2d1e01c71fad0366e0c200207a75487`
parameters.name: maker

parameters.description: Filter to a particular user, e.g. `0x4d04eb67a2d1e01c71fad0366e0c200207a75487`
parameters.name: contract

parameters.description:
`active` = currently valid, `inactive` = temporarily invalid, `expired` = permanently invalid

Available when filtering by maker, otherwise only valid orders will be returned
parameters.name: status

get.summary: Tokens with metadata
get.description: Get a list of tokens with full metadata. This is useful for showing a single token page, or scenarios that require more metadata. If you don't need this metadata, you should use the tokens API, which is much faster.

get.summary: Get updates any time the floor price of a collection changes
get.description:
Every time the floor price of a collection changes (i.e. the 'floor ask'), an event is generated. This API is designed to be polled at high frequency, in order to keep an external system in sync with accurate prices for any token.

There are multiple event types, which describe what caused the change in price:

- `new-order` > new listing at a lower price

- `expiry` > the previous best listing expired

- `sale` > the previous best listing was filled

- `cancel` > the previous best listing was cancelled

- `balance-change` > the best listing was invalidated due to no longer owning the NFT

- `approval-change` > the best listing was invalidated due to revoked approval

- `revalidation` > manual revalidation of orders (e.g. after a bug fixed) 

- `bootstrap` > initial loading of data, so that all tokens have a price associated

Some considerations to keep in mind

- Due to the complex nature of monitoring off-chain liquidity across multiple marketplaces, including dealing with block re-orgs, events should be considered 'relative' to the perspective of the indexer, ie _when they were discovered_, rather than _when they happened_. A more deterministic historical record of price changes is in development, but in the meantime, this method is sufficent for keeping an external system in sync with the best available prices.

- Events are only generated if the best price changes. So if a new order or sale happens without changing the best price, no event is generated. This is more common with 1155 tokens, which have multiple owners and more depth. For this reason, if you need sales data, use the Sales API.

parameters.description: Get events after a particular unix timestamp (inclusive)
parameters.name: startTimestamp

parameters.description: Get events before a particular unix timestamp (inclusive)
parameters.name: endTimestamp

- `sale` > the previous best listing was filled

- `cancel` > the previous best listing was cancelled

- `balance-change` > the best listing was invalidated due to no longer owning the NFT

- `approval-change` > the best listing was invalidated due to revoked approval

- `revalidation` > manual revalidation of orders (e.g. after a bug fixed) 

- `bootstrap` > initial loading of data, so that all tokens have a price associated

Some considerations to keep in mind

- Due to the complex nature of monitoring off-chain liquidity across multiple marketplaces, including dealing with block re-orgs, events should be considered 'relative' to the perspective of the indexer, ie _when they were discovered_, rather than _when they happened_. A more deterministic historical record of price changes is in development, but in the meantime, this method is sufficent for keeping an external system in sync with the best available prices.

- Events are only generated if the best price changes. So if a new order or sale happens without changing the best price, no event is generated. This is more common with 1155 tokens, which have multiple owners and more depth. For this reason, if you need sales data, use the Sales API.

parameters.description: Filter to a particular token, e.g. `0x8d04a8c79ceb0889bdd12acdf3fa9d207ed3ff63:123`
parameters.name: token
